intro: Grumilea micrococca, commonly known as the dwarf grumihua, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its small, clustered flowers that are typically pink or white in color. It thrives in high-altitude environments and requires well-drained soil and full sun exposure. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens, though it is not widely known outside of its native habitat.
